body:
I'd probably do it this way. Instead of loading Google in the mainWindow using loadUrl I'd instead create a basic HTML page that contains a webview that loads Google. I'd then create a small JS file to load in the webview preload. This script would require jQuery like this:

``` javascript
window.$ = window.jQuery = require('./bower_components/jquery/dist/jquery.min.js');
```

Then in that small script I'd do whatever other code you need to do in order to intercept and manipulate elements on the Google page.

At least that is what I am thinking off the top of my head. I'm sure there are other ways to do it.
That works. Thank you. :-)
Actually, I am still stuck on getting the elements of the page. How do I access them?
I'll try to come up with an example. Give me a few minutes.

@frankhale Thanks a ton! My head was spinning understanding what is available in which process!

Thank you! :-)
You're welcome! Let me know if you have any other questions. I'll try to help out if I can!

**frankhale** thanks, great info. 
Is that possible in _manipulateGoogle.js_ inject locally-stored scripts with relative path?

Webviews are capable of injecting local scripts by using the preload tag (see above example). 

https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/web-view-tag.md#preload

Thx, 
Is there any way to do this in the case of multiple scripts (without concatenation)?
I guess you could load a script that in turn loads other scripts to get around only being able to pass one script to preload tag.

Yeah, I did so.
And it looks like I'm not able to use relative paths to scripts.

Check that your paths are pointing to a correct location. I typically use __dirname and sometimes use ./ to build my relative paths.

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8131344/what-is-the-difference-between-dirname-and-in-node-js

There are some Electron APIs to get various useful paths:

https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/app.md#appgetapppath
https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/app.md#appgetpathname

There really shouldn't be any reason why a relative path would be a problem here. The preload tag has access to the node environment (at least initially if node integration is turned off). If you want to use node modules you'll need to make sure node integration remains on in the webview.
You could start up a HTTP server to serve the scripts and avoid the issue with relative paths. Just add new script tags to the page in your preload script with the paths to the scripts you want.
**frankhale**, thanks, nice idea

This is very helpful, however if the app navigates to a new page within the URL my rendered div disappears. Is there a way to make the JQuery `$("#lst-ib").val("Hello, World!");` call run after each page finishes loading ?
Scratch the last comment - it actually works as is. It just got written to a different place in the page.
You need to open the dev tools for the webview to see console log statements.
I thought I did using the "view, toggle developer tools" then "view, reload" but it doesn't log anything.
@carlskii, are you able to see the console log statements in the webviews dev tools now?
Yes thanks - that did the trick.

If it's the browser window and you have node integration turned on you can get to it from both sides. Eg. if it's in main.js then you can use IPC to communicate from your browser side JS to the backend main.js code to call it. Or you can use the Remote API from your browser side code to grab the current BrowserWindow object and then call the method you need. If node integration is turned off you can do it via Socket IO (or similar technology) to communicate from the browser code to the main.js code in order to call the method.

Remote API: https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/remote.md

Webview can be done in pretty much the same fashion, if node-integration is turned off wire up an event handler in your preload script so that it can be called from the code loading in the webview. If it's turned on do it like above (whatever you prefer).

There may be other ways to do it but this is just off the top of my head. If any of my info is wrong somebody please feel free to correct me.

Thanks for this. 

Wow, Electron certainly seems to get complicated here. I previously used NW.js for some other projects. Are there any references/tutorials for that cover this bidirectional IPC configs ?

So yeah, Electron has built in API to do IPC and the docs are here:

https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/ipc-main.md
https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/master/docs/api/ipc-renderer.md

I've only briefly used the in-built IPC API so can't really comment much on it. I've also used Socket IO as a "IPC" mechanism and found it to work rather nicely. You could probably use other APIs to communicate back and forth but I haven't really explored it because Socket IO worked well for me in this regard.

Thanks again @frankhale. 

Going back to your `manipulateGoogle.js` example which now after further investigation I understand whats happening. However, most of my page elements are created and built using AJAX requests which means there's nothing for the jquery selectors to find until the page is built.  

Appreciate, this is more of a jquery question (maybe), but is there a way to wait until the subsequent page build completes before firing `$(document).ready` ?

(I haven't tried this but...) If you have control over the code that you are loading (eg you can edit it) why not set up a callback in your webview preload and then when your page gets done loading all it's ajax stuff then call the callback from the code loaded in the webview to notify it that your page is done doing everything so you can then manipulate it as needed from the webview preload script.
Yeah, thats the problem, I don't have control of the code in the pages I'm loading.

okay no problem, here is a possible work around. Maybe there is something you can look for in the page when you know the page may be finished loading and then trigger some code to manipulate the results. I'm thinking set up an interval to periodically do something and then remove the interval after some time or maybe even setup a timeout to run the manipulate code after a number of seconds have passed.

@TimNZ That's because you are waiting for the window load event before `require` jQuery.  This means the `document` object is fully populated and the DOM is rendered.

You can't do what are you doing without the `onload` function

Can by any chance confirm, that the above example of manipulation www.google.com still works?
Got up to the point of preloading the script, in which i put an alert(); and works fine. But i cant get the text swapping work with the jquery.
Thanx
